moves.2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nf3: As is expected from higher-rated players, my opp doesn't go for the naive Nc3 - which is good, but I am used to play against it.
moves.3... Bg4 4. Be2 Nf6 5. c4: A good one for white in this scheme.
moves.5... Qa5: Preventing white to move d4 for a moment, and a step toward Qc2.
moves.6. Nc3 c6: Necessary to control knight's jumps to the 5th rank.
moves.7. O-O Nbd7 8. d4: Strong and normally enough to win.
moves.8... e6: At this point, white's moves are d5 or Bf4.
moves.9. Bd2 Qc7: At last. Now the black diagonal is covered.
moves.10... h5: This is the best part of a "my" Scandinavian.
moves.11... hxg4: Black recovers the piece because of Qh2#
moves.14. f4 Qh5: Renewing the threat. I think it is better than c5+ at once.
moves.16. Be3 Qh4+: Not g3+, since after Ke1 the white king is almost shielded.
moves.17. g3 Qh2+ 18. Ke1: Black can recover the piece here, but I like to attack. Chess is about it.
moves.18... Qxg3+ 19. Bf2 Bxf2+ 20. Rxf2 Rh1+: White is struggling to shield his king.
moves.21... Rd8 22. Qe2 Rd3: I think it was the right way to go on with the attack, threatening Re3.
moves.23. Qxd3: I think white gave up the game here, in a certain way.
moves.23... Qxd3: Or it was a simple overlook that the bishop is pinned. Anyway, black was even in material (now with a huge advantage) even before the queen's sac.
moves.27. Rd4: Nice, white wants to further exchange material in order to free his position.
moves.27... c5: Giving him a push, just to be sure.
moves.28. Rxe4 Qxe4: White can take the g3 pawn, now.
moves.29... Qb1+ 30. Kd2 Rxf1: Or Qxb2+. But black is confident the game is won.
moves.31. Rb3 Qe1+: After Kmoves, black has plenty of ways to further exchange material and win, so my opponent resigned.

gameName: A clean blitz win against a 2000 player
